items.item_text_raw: 1. 4:30 p.m. - The Meeting will be called to order at the District Board Room, 40 South Market Street, San Jose, CA 95113

items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
This is an opportunity for members of the public to address the Board concerning issues not listed on the agenda.
	 
The Board welcomes this opportunity to hear from the public and has established a policy for the public's participation in board meetings, which is outlined in BP 2345. This policy states that:
	 
No member of the public may speak without being recognized by the President of the Board.
Each speaker will be allowed a maximum of three minutes per topic. Thirty minutes shall be the maximum time allotment for public speakers on any one subject regardless of the number of speakers at any one Board meeting. At the discretion of a majority of the Board, these time limits may be extended.
The Board recognizes the need to encourage public participation but also recognizes the need to preserve order and the proper functioning of the meeting. Citizens addressing the Board at meetings shall therefore conduct themselves at all times in a manner appropriate to the setting.

items.item_details:
1. San Jose City College Adjunct Faculty
Per the collective bargaining agreement between the Faculty Association AFT 6157 and San Jose/Evergreen Community College District Article 9.13 submission and recommendation: Adjunct faculty members shall be responsible and accountable for all District assigned services during the college semester for which they are employed. Assignments are limited to a maximum of 67% of the full load.
Article 9.13 ASSIGNMENT LENGTH AND MAXIMUM LOADING - Adjunct faculty members shall be responsible and accountable for all District assigned service during the college semester for which they are employed. Assignments are limited to a maximum of 67% of a full load.
Therefore, the attached information is in compliance with Article 9.13 of the Faculty Association AFT 6157 Collective Bargaining Agreement with San Jose/Evergreen Community College District.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the faculty personnel action as submitted

items.item_details: The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees. Board Policy 6100 established the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval. All contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions exceeding the current bid limit of $86,000 shall have prior Board approval as a separate board item.
	 
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $1,000, as well as additional contracts, although not executed by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees ratify the contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions for the period of September 10, 2015 through October 9, 2015 as noted in the attached documents.
items.item_text: Ratification of Contracts, Purchase Orders and Contract Revisions
items.item_text_raw: 8. Ratification of Contracts, Purchase Orders and Contract Revisions

items.item_details:
Per California Public Contract Code Section 30652, "the governing board of any community college district without advertising for bids, and when the board has determined it to be the best interest of the district, may authorize by contract, lease, requisition or purchase order ... (to) purchase materials, supplies, equipment ... and other personal property for the district in the manner in which the public corporation or agency is authorized by law to make the lease or purchase." The contract must be based on the same prices and upon the same terms and conditions of a negotiated contract between the supplier and another public corporation agency.
	 
Therefore, when considering the best interest for the District, it is recommended that the Board of Trustees award a piggybackable contract between NASPO ValuePoint Cooperative Purchasing Organization (formerly WSCA-NASPO) and Dell Marketing, LLP, without the need to further advertise for bids on an already competitively bid contract. NASPO ValuePoint Cooperative Purchasing Organization provides the highest standard of excellence in public cooperative contracting by leveraging the leadership and expertise of all states with the purchasing power of their public entities, delivering best value, reliable and competitively sourced contracts.
	 
Attached are a proof of publication, California Participating Addendum No. 7-15-70-34-003 and a WSCA-NASPO Master Agreement Award awarding Dell Marketing, LLP a three year contract effective 04/01/2015 to 03/31/2017, with an extension option of an additional 36 months.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees authorized the District to 'piggyback' on a contract with Dell Marketing, LLP.
items.item_text: Piggyback Dell Marketing, LLP Contract
items.item_text_raw: 9. Piggyback Dell Marketing, LLP Contract

ENGR 504:  Technical and Contextualized Communication

items.item_details:
On November 11, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved a contract to C. Overaa & Company in the amount of $11,347,704 to provide construction services for the Automotive Technology Building Project at Evergreen Valley College.   
	 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions or District requested design changes that require an adjustment to the contract scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 010 includes additional building signage to obtain the Leadership in Energy & Environmental Design (LEED) certification, installation of redwood header board at the Autotech firelane, installation of a water line to accommodate a future refrigerator installation, changes to exterior spandrel glass thickness for increased Ultra Violet (UV) protection, wall layout modifications to (5) staff offices, reroute conduit and dispose of transite pipe discovered during excavation for landscape bioswales, additional hand excavation to provide vertical separation between the irrigation mainline and sewer line as required by the City of San Jose, and added costs for disposal of organic and lime-treated soil discovered during site grading activities.
	 
C. Overaa & Company submitted written pricing proposals for these changes (details in the Agenda attachment) that include the applicable increase or decrease in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions and overhead and profit.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount               $11,347,704
Previous Approved Changes          $  1,811,163
Change Order No. 010                   $     131,976   
Total Contract and Changes           $13,290,843
	 
The net change to C. Overaa & Company's contract as a result of all changes issued is $1,943,139, which equates to 17.12% of the original contract.  Legal counsel has reviewed this change; while the cumulative amount for change orders for this project now exceeds ten percent he has affirmed it is not applicable for this Lease Lease-Back (LLB) contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 010 in the amount of $131,976 to C. Overaa & Company for the Automotive Technology Building Project #32111 at Evergreen Valley College.
items.item_text: Measure G – 2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College Automotive Technology Building, Project #32111 - C. Overaa & Company Change Order No. 010
items.item_text_raw: 2. Measure G – 2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College Automotive Technology Building, Project #32111 - C. Overaa & Company Change Order No. 010

items.item_details:
Utilizing the public bidding process, on August 17, 2015 the Selection Committee (which included the Furniture Consultant, District Purchasing, and College Deans) reviewed and evaluated the unit prices and several proposed alternates of the pieces of equipment proposed by the three bidders:  Precor Commercial Fitness, Precor Incorporated, and Life Fitness in response to the ‘EVC South Campus Development Fitness Center Cardio Equipment’ RFP (BID G2010.0132). 
	 
Precor Commercial Fitness (ICA Revision No. 001) to include a piece of equipment that was previously awarded to another vendor during bid, but was incorrectly quoted and subsequently withdrawn.  Precor Commercial Fitness is contracted for the supply and installation of other cardio fitness equipment to the South Campus Development Project at EVC. 
	 
Life Fitness was the lowest bidder of one (1) of the specified pieces of equipment and was awarded an ICA accordingly.  Shortly after, Life Fitness informed the District Purchasing Department that it made a clerical error in the bid, accidentally quoting the wrong model, and therefore requested to withdraw their bid.  The District agreed, leaving Precor Commercial Fitness as the next lowest bidder for this equipment at a bid price of $4,195.00 plus tax.  Precor Commercial Fitness confirmed they would include the equipment for a total add of $4,562.00 by revision to their executed ICA.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Revision No. 001 of the Independent Contractor Agreement (ICA) to Precor Commercial Fitness in the amount of $4,562 for the South Campus Development Project at Evergreen Valley College (EVC).
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College (EVC) South Campus Development Project #32107 – Precor Commercial Fitness Independent Contractor Agreement (ICA) Revision No. 001
items.item_text_raw: 3. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College (EVC) South Campus Development Project #32107 – Precor Commercial Fitness Independent Contractor Agreement (ICA) Revision No. 001

items.item_details:
On August 26, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved an Agreement to Blach Construction Company in the amount of $41,639,729 to provide construction services for the South Campus Development Project #32107 at Evergreen Valley College.
Change Order No. 011 includes Work that is the result of costs and credits from: the addition of (12) door contact switches for Building A, addition of a card reader and electrified hardware for door A126, credit from the revised window coverings for Building A, credit from the deletion of soap dispensers and towel bars within the bathroom sinks and showers, addition of a revised toilet paper dispenser for the non-accessible bathrooms stalls, credit from revising (4) fire extinguisher cabinets from recessed to surface mounted and the addition of revised site furnishings for campus landscaping.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms. 
	 
Original Contract Amount                     $41,639,729.00
Previous Approved Changes                $     392,392.00
Change Order No. 011                         $       11,829.00
Total Contract and Changes                 $42,043,950.00
	 
The net change to Blach Construction Company’s contract as a result of all changes issued is $404,221.00 which equates to 0.97% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 011 in the amount of $11,829.00 to Blach Construction Company for the South Campus Development Project #32107 at Evergreen Valley College.

On May 26, 2015, the Board of Trustees approved a contract to Environmental Systems Inc. in the amount of $1,063,900 to provide construction services or products for GE HVAC Upgrades and Campus HVAC Controls Extension Project #31127 at SJCC.
	 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions; District requested or design changes that require an adjustment to the contract, scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 003 is for:
	 
Environmental Systems Inc. will upgrade the Building Management System (BMS) server to District Standards, remodel GE-204 Building Distribution Facility (BDF) to support the Network Upgrade Project for the San Jose Community College campus, zero dollar change to land the District Office Graphics to the Front End BMS server, and a zero dollar time extension of 30 days to remodel GE-204 BDF to support the campus wide network upgrade project.
                     
Environmental Systems Inc. submitted a written pricing proposal for these changes (details in the attachment) that include the applicable increase or decrease in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions and overhead and profit.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                    $1,063,900.00   
Previously Approved Changes            $     80,319.00
Change Order No. 003                        $     16,148.00
	 
Revised Contract Amount                    $1,160,367.00
	 
The net change to Environmental Systems Inc. contract as a result of all changes issued is $96,467.00 which, equates to 9.1% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 003 in the amount of $16,148 to Environmental Systems, Inc. for the GE HVAC Upgrades and Campus HVAC Controls Extension Project #31127 at SJCC.

items.item_details:
The scope of this Agreement is to provide design service to support the San Jose City College’s Campus Network Upgrade Project. Scope of design services include preparation of construction documents, bid phase service, construction management and close out service to replace the Uninterrupted Power Supply (UPS) equipment, which provides power to the Main Distribution Facility (MDF), San Jose City College’s Network and Data Center. The existing equipment has reached its serviceable life, and requires replacement to ensure reliable network coverage.
	 
Salas O’Brien was selected through a competitive process from the on-call pool of AE firms; Salas O’Brien was the engineer of record for the installation of the original UPS equipment and subsequent backup generator project, which are integral to the replacement project.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the award of an Agreement in the amount of $25,000.00 to Salas O’Brien, for Design Services, IT and Tech Equipment: MDF-UPS Replacement project #31702.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: San Jose City College, IT and Tech Equipment: MDF – UPS Replacement Project #31702, Design Agreement - Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) to the Master Agreement, PAA #SJCC-07 – Salas O’Brien.
items.item_text_raw: 7. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: San Jose City College, IT and Tech Equipment: MDF – UPS Replacement Project #31702, Design Agreement - Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) to the Master Agreement, PAA #SJCC-07 – Salas O’Brien.

items.item_details:
On February 11, 2014, the Board agreed to enter into a contract with CampusWorks per Bid Proposal G21010.0069 Ellucian Colleague Conversion to MS SQL (B0011261). Revision No. 002 to the Independent Contractor Agreement is to provide additional project services for the Oracle to Microsoft SQL Conversion for the Ellucian Colleague system (attached). 
	 
The additional project services are needed for user training, testing and additional programming work for custom programs in the new SQL environment. The user training and testing services will be for four weeks onsite at a total cost of $28,000 (160 hours). The programming services will be for up to 160 hours of work performed remotely at a cost of $175 per hour for a total cost not to exceed $28,000. 
	 
Original Contract Amount:      $2,678,562.50
Revision #001                        $     98,000.00
Revision #002                        $     56,000.00
	 
	 
Total Contract and Revisions:  $2,832,562.50
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Revision No. 002 to the CampusWorks ICA in the amount of $56,000 for User-Training, Testing and Programming services for the Colleague Conversion to MS SQL at the District Office.

items.item_details: The Board of Trustees adopted the District's operating budget at its meeting of September 8, 2015.  As required by Board Policy 6250 subsequent budget transfers and revisions must be approved by the Board of Trustees.

items.item_details: On October 30, 2015, President Obama issued a Presidential Proclamation proclaiming November 2015 as National Native American Heritage Month. In support of this proclamation and in celebration of the achievements of Native American faculty, administrators, staff and students, the San JosĂŠ-Evergreen Community College District participates in events in which Native American culture is celebrated. It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve Resolution No. 111015-2 in support of November 2015 as Native American Heritage Month.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Resolution No. 111015-2 to designate November 2015 as Native American Heritage Month.

items.item_details: In May 2015, the California state legislature passed Assembly Concurrent Resolution 37 and declared November 2015 as âSikh American Awareness and Appreciation Month.â  This Resolution would recognize and acknowledge the significant contributions made by Californians of Sikh heritage to the State and afford all Californians the opportunity to understand, recognize, and appreciate the rich history and shared principles of Sikh Americans. It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve Resolution No. 111015-3 in support of November 2015 as Sikh American Awareness and Appreciation Month.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Resolution No. 111015-3 to designate November 2015 as Sikh American Awareness and Appreciation Month.

items.item_details:
On October 9, 2012, the Board of Trustees of the San Jose-Evergreen Community College District and the Milpitas Unified School District approved a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to create a joint educational facility in Milpitas, which was named the Joint-Use 21st Century Post-Secondary Education Center. 
	 
However, as a result of recent discussions with the Milpitas Unified School District and the Office of the State Chancellor, it was concluded that the name of the facility must be changed. The State Chancellor will preclude use of the term "Educational Center."  Furthermore, accreditation standards mandate that a Center is a separately accredited institution. The joint-use facility is not projected to meet either the State Chancellor or accreditation standards criteria over the next decade or longer.
	 
Since construction of the new San Jose-Evergreen Community College Extension is underway, and classes are scheduled to begin in Fall, 2016, it is important for this new facility to have a functional name in place. The district could change the name of the facility in the future. For the purposes of accreditation, the facility must be assigned to one college. Current student enrollment preference, quantity of respective college course and section offerings, distance and time comparisons align the Milpitas community more closely with San Jose City College than to Evergreen Valley College. As the lead college, San Jose City College will be responsible for site management, student support services, and overall community relations. San Jose City College is in the process of incorporating the facility in its accreditation self-study.
	 
It is, therefore, recommended that the Board of Trustees approve naming the new facility San Jose-Evergreen Community College Extension, a partnership with the Milpitas Unified School District and identify San Jose City College as lead college for operations for the Extension. This action will give direction for the site and building signage, accreditation self-studies and for public discussions.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees name the new joint use educational facility the San Jose-Evergreen Community College Extension, a partnership with the Milpitas Unified School District and also identify San Jose City College as the lead college for operations of the Extension.
items.item_text: Naming and Identification of lead college for the Joint SJECCD/MUSD Facility
items.item_text_raw: 4. Naming and Identification of lead college for the Joint SJECCD/MUSD Facility

items.item_details:
This Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) establishes a cooperative and mutually beneficial relationship between the Silicon Valley Regional Interoperability Authority (SVRIA) and San Jose/Evergreen Community College District (SJECCD).
	 
The goal of the SRVIA is to create and implement a strategy for a regional public safety communications system, to participate in regional interoperability systems, to jointly fund activities and systems related to interoperability and to jointly apply for grants and funding.
	 
The SRVIA System is planned to replace the existing public safety radio system(s) currently in use in Santa Clara County with a new digital P25 component using a spectrum of 700 MHz.  The system will utilize new and existing repeater sites developed to ensure coverage in the more remote areas of the County. All repeater sites and dispatch centers will be connected through the EComm microwave system that was developed using Department of Homeland Security (DHS) grants.
	 
The cost of joining this SVRIA is distributed among the participatory agencies that are identified in the MOU.  With our membership, it will represent all law enforcement agencies within Santa Clara County as members with the SVRIA.  Exhibit A shows the implementation costs for SJECCD, beginning in fiscal year 2015-16, and the two succeeding years will be $22,691.  Beginning in fiscal year 2018-19, as shown in Exhibit B of the MOU, the Districtâs share of the projected operations and maintenance costs will be $8,233, with a very modest escalator in subsequent years.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Memorandum of Understanding between the Silicon Valley Regional Interoperability Authority and the San Jose/Evergreen Community College District.
items.item_text: MOU between the Silicon Valley Regional Interoperability Authority (SVRIA) and SJECCD
items.item_text_raw: 5. MOU between the Silicon Valley Regional Interoperability Authority (SVRIA) and SJECCD

items.item_details:
On October 14, 2014, the Board of Trustees awarded Cambridge West, LLC with a contract to help the colleges update their educational master plan.  In November, 2014, Cambridge West Partnership teams lead a kick-off effort on the campuses of San Jose City College and Evergreen Valley College that included focus groups with faculty, staff, and students.  Since then, Cambridge West teams have completed internal and external environmental scans, surveys of faculty and students, analysis of classroom capacity and course productivity, and a series of walkabouts designed to capture the feel of the campuses from a facilities perspective.  During Spring 2015 the team engaged in further questionnaires, interviews, open houses, and presentations, including meeting with each college's Academic Senate and Executive Committee.  In Fall 2015, final EMP plans were presented at Professional Development Day as well as at the Steering Committee for each college.   
	 
A working draft of the Educational Master Plan has been posted to each of the colleges’ public web pages.  All campus constituency groups, key committees and communities have been advised of the URL to find the draft EMP documents.  The Final Educational Master Plans are complete  and are presented for Board of Trustees review and approval.
	 
The Educational Master Plan include recommendations for additional space to 2030 for each college, including Language Arts, Math & Science, Nursing, and SHAPE classrooms for EVC and Math & Science, Language Arts, Humanities & Social Science classrooms, and Business & Workforce laboratory space for SJCC.  Conclusions by Cambridge West are coupled with observations about both colleges with respect to: high quality educational programs; well-placed initiatives that have already been started; numerous faculty ideas for new curriculum and student support services; contribution to the community; and opportunity for future enrollment growth.  
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Evergreen Valley College and the San Jose City College Educational Master Plans as presented.
items.item_text: EVC and SJCC Educational Master Plan Final Report
items.item_text_raw: 6. EVC and SJCC Educational Master Plan Final Report

items.item_details:
As part of the accountability measures for the Measure G-2004 Bond Program, the management team for the program has put into place a formal process for managing, tracking and presenting to the Board of Trustees all revisions to the Measure G-2004 individual project names, scopes and budgets.  This process adheres to the accountability standards outlined by Proposition 39 and provides transparency in the evolution of the project list.
	 
In response to input received from the Board, additional criteria was added to the Bond List Revision process at the August 25th, 2015, Board of Trustees’ meeting.  This criteria identified an added layer of information and flagging to a Bond List Revision for those projects with substantive changes (a budget change to a single project in excess of $5 million dollars, the cancellation of a project from the bond list, or the creation of a new project).  Receiving further input from the Board, the management team will now separate Bond List Revisions containing “substantive changes” onto a separate, stand alone, Bond List Revision.  In the agenda text, the team will state whether or not the item contains substantive changes.
	 
This Bond List Revision does not contain substantive changes based on the criteria set forth above.  This Bond List Revision includes the allocation of interest earnings.
	 
Please refer to the attached Bond List Revisions Approval Request report and the Summary of Current Changes report for details on the project revision included on the G-2004 Bond List Revision dated November 10, 2015.
	 
These Bond List Revisions have been approved by the San Jose City College Vice President of Administrative Services, the Evergreen Valley College President and the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees review and approve the revisions to the Measure G - 2004 bond list, as presented.
items.item_text: Measure G-2004 Bond Program: Bond List Revision
items.item_text_raw: 7. Measure G-2004 Bond Program: Bond List Revision

items.item_details:
As part of the accountability measures for the Measure G-2010 Bond Program, the management team for the program has put into place a formal process for managing, tracking and presenting to the Board of Trustees all revisions to the Measure G-2010 individual project names, scopes and budgets.  This process adheres to the accountability standards outlined by Proposition 39 and provides transparency in the evolution of the project list.
	 
In response to input received from the Board, additional criteria was added to the Bond List Revision process at the August 25th, 2015, Board of Trustees’ meeting.  This criteria identified an added layer of information and flagging to a Bond List Revision for those projects with substantive changes (a budget change to a single project in excess of $5 million dollars, the cancellation of a project from the bond list, or the creation of a new project).  Receiving further input from the Board, the management team will now separate Bond List Revisions containing “substantive changes” onto a separate, stand alone, Bond List Revision.  In the agenda text, the team will state whether or not the item contains substantive changes.
	 
Measure G-2010 Bond List Revision No. 17 does not contain substantive changes based on the criteria set forth above.  This revision recognizes interest earnings, moves project savings from Evergreen Valley College’s (EVC) Project #32107 South Campus Development to #32111 Automotive Technology and to #32307 Schedule Maintenance, as well as distributes the excess EVC Campus Contingency and distributes the excess Program Contingency.
	 
At the start of the bond program, each Campus Contingency was set at 5% of the campus program.  The Program Contingency account was set at 3% of the program. As projects are completed, risk is reduced, and the contingency percentage goes up.   These budget moves represent the distribution of contingency above the 5% for EVC’s College Contingency and above 3% for Program Contingency.  
	 
Please refer to the attached Bond List Revisions Approval Request report and the Summary of Current Changes report for details on each project revision included on the G-2010 Bond List Revision No. 17 dated November 10, 2015.
	 
These Bond List Revisions have been approved by the San Jose City College Vice President of Administrative Services, the Evergreen Valley College President and the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees review and approve the revisions to the Measure G - 2010 bond list, as presented.

items.item_details: Each year, the Workforce Institute provides the Board of Trustees with an overview and update of the previous yearâs activities.  The presentation this year will start by characterizing how the staff of the Workforce Institute approaches federal, state, and local priorities as well as market drivers with just-in-time flexibility. We will highlight our programs and services from this past year and show how we are laying a strong foundation for the current year. Highlights include the various grants awarded and/or implemented, corporate contracts secured and our job readiness activities designed to help unemployed and underemployed adults and opportunity youth here in San Jose and Silicon Valley. This presentation will culminate with showing how our efforts contribute to the Global Ends Policies established by our Board of Trustees.

items.item_details:
Administrative Procedure 6380 stipulates that "The District's goal is to remove any and all barriers to a full and equal opportunity for minority-owned or [women]-owned businesses to provide products and services to the District... No vendor shall be excluded from consideration for, or award of, District purchases on the basis of ethnic group identification, race, color, language, accent, immigration status, ancestry, national origin, age, gender, religion, sexual orientation, transgender, marital status, veteran status, physical or mental disability, or on the basis of these characteristics or association with a person or group with one or more of these characteristics."
	 
District staff and Gilbane Construction recognizes the importance of supplier diversity, and continue to encourage participation by minority-owned, women-owned and small business enterprises. Annually, the Board of Trustees are informed of the prior fiscal year results of our continuous effort in this endeavor. Along with prior year's results, today's annual update compares three years of information (FY 2012-2013, FY 2013-2014 and FY 2014-2015) on the diversity of the District's vendors. The data includes all District vendors that received payment for goods and services rendered for the respective FYs.

items.item_details:
Per its adopted governing principles, the Board of Trustees will evaluate its performance at the end of each meeting.
	 
The Board will consider two items in discussing its evaluation:
	 
1.To ascertain the effectiveness of the meeting in attaining the advancement of the Board's Global Ends Policy.
	 
2.To ascertain the degree to which Trustees adhered to the Board adopted Governance Principle: Trustees Code of Conduct.
